lg.l: Gone is the stream from your mouth.
By torchlight we search the Phoenix Park,
where once they found buried in the dirt
a shelled necklace, a flint blade, a toggle
made of bone five thousand years ago.
Tonight even the long oaks seem lost.
I think of the dumb, rubber ball
on the kitchen floor, the empty water bowl
shining. It is the first time I see you weep.
What moves in the shadows is unknown,
though I can hear the shy deer creeping
at the edges, bellies shaped into the night,
eyes bright as skeletons inside the tomb
at Knockmaree on this Samhein eve.
Small fires fall in the honour of the dead.
We spread a blanket upon the grass.
She will know this place by scent, you say
as you lean like a river to the earth.
